stem: A 28-year-old client is being treated for severe preeclampsia with a magnesium sulfate infusion. During the hourly assessment, she is difficult to rouse. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Suspected magnesium toxicity.
Background: Receiving magnesium sulfate at 2 g/hr for 18 hours.
Assessment: Client responds only to painful stimuli. Muscle tone is flaccid.
Recommendation: Immediate reversal and airway protection.

tabs.title: Magnesium Toxicity Flowsheet
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemCurrent FindingInterpretation
Deep Tendon Reflexes0 (Absent)Magnesium Toxicity
Respiratory Rate9 breaths/min (Shallow)Severe Depression
Urine Output10 mL/hr (for 4 hrs)Oliguria (Risk for toxic build-up)
Blood Pressure92/54 mmHgHypotension

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 92/54 mmHg, HR 58 bpm, RR 9 breaths/min, T 98.2°F, SpO2 88% on room air.

actionOptions.text: Stop the magnesium sulfate infusion immediately.
Administer calcium gluconate IV as prescribed.
Increase the IV rate of magnesium sulfate to stabilize the blood pressure.
Perform a vigorous fundal massage to rouse the client.

parameterOptions.text: Respiratory rate and continuous pulse oximetry
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This client has magnesium sulfate toxicity (c2), as evidenced by the 'Toxic Triad': absent reflexes (0), respiratory depression (<12 breaths/min), and decreased level of consciousness. The oliguria (10 mL/hr) likely caused the drug to accumulate to toxic levels. Priority #1 is stopping the infusion (a1), and Priority #2 is administering the antidote, calcium gluconate (a2). Key parameters are the respiratory rate (p1) to track airway safety and deep tendon reflexes (p2) to track neuromuscular recovery.
clinicalPearls: Reflexes disappear FIRST (at ~9–12 mg/dL), followed by respiratory depression (at ~12–15 mg/dL).
Magnesium is the 'muscle relaxant'—toxicity leads to everything going 'limp' (muscles, heart, lungs).
Always have calcium gluconate at the bedside when magnesium sulfate is infusing.

questionTrap.trap: Calling a Rapid Response before stopping the infusion.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Stopping the infusion is the FIRST action! If you leave it running while waiting for help, the patient will stop breathing.

mnemonic.title: B-U-R-P (Mag Toxicity)
mnemonic.expansion: B-BP Decreased. U-Urine Output low (<30 mL/hr). R-Reflexes absent. P-Pulmonary (RR < 12 breaths/min).
